question: Does ultrasound exposure at clinically relevant intensities (0.1-3 W/cm², 1-3 MHz diagnostic or 20-100 kHz therapeutic) alter VDAC1 oligomeric state through outer mitochondrial membrane lipid reorganization? Specifically: (1) Can mechanical energy at these frequencies propagate to the OMM with sufficient intensity to reorganize cholesterol/cardiolipin domains? (2) If so, does lipid domain reorganization shift VDAC1 between honeycomb (protected) and dispersed (oligomerization-competent) states? (3) Does the altered lipid environment of cancer cell OMMs (elevated cholesterol, reduced cardiolipin) change the threshold for mechanically-induced VDAC1 state transitions compared to healthy cells?

gate.recommendation: Lab Gate PASSED. 18/18 claims cleared all three criteria. Proceeding to S4 hypothesis operationalization.

hypotheses.prediction: IF OMM cholesterol is depleted by MβCD (5-10 mM, 30 min), THEN VDAC1 oligomerization (measured by EGS crosslinking and VDAC1-FRET) will increase >2-fold relative to vehicle, with concurrent loss of VDAC1 honeycomb clustering (>40% decrease in cluster size by STORM).

IF isolated mitochondria are exposed to 1-3 MHz ultrasound at 0.1-3 W/cm² ISPTA in degassed buffer (cavitation suppressed), THEN Laurdan generalized polarization (GP) of the OMM will change by <0.02 GP units (within noise), compared to >0.05 GP shift with positive control MβCD cholesterol depletion.

IF isolated mitochondria are exposed to 40 kHz ultrasound at 1-3 W/cm² in air-saturated buffer, THEN OMM lipid domain reorganization (Laurdan GP decrease >0.05 and cholesterol-filipin puncta dispersal >30%) will occur; this effect will be abolished (>80% reduction) in degassed buffer.

IF cancer cells (MCF-7, HeLa) and matched normal cells (MCF-10A, HEK293) are exposed to graded mechanical perturbation (MβCD titration as lipid disruption proxy, or 40 kHz US with cavitation), THEN cancer cells will show a sharper sigmoidal dose-response curve for VDAC1 oligomerization (Hill coefficient >3 vs. <2 for normal cells) with a higher intensity threshold (EC50 ~1.3-2× that of normal cells), but greater maximal response.

protocols.prediction: IF isolated mitochondria are exposed to 1-3 MHz ultrasound at 0.1-3 W/cm² ISPTA in degassed buffer (cavitation suppressed), THEN Laurdan generalized polarization (GP) of the OMM will change by <0.02 GP units (within noise), compared to >0.05 GP shift with positive control MβCD cholesterol depletion.
protocols.protocol: Isolate mitochondria from HeLa cells by differential centrifugation, load with Laurdan (5 μM, 30 min). Expose in degassed vs. non-degassed PBS to pulsed US (1 MHz and 3 MHz, 0.5/1.0/3.0 W/cm², 60s) using a calibrated transducer with hydrophone verification. Image Laurdan GP by two-photon microscopy immediately pre/post. Parallel samples with 5 mM MβCD (30 min) as positive control. Timeline: 2 weeks.
controls: heat-matched control (water bath to US-equivalent ΔT)
protocols.expected_outcome: No significant Laurdan GP change in degassed conditions at any intensity; possible GP shift (>0.03) only in non-degassed samples at ≥1 W/cm² (cavitation-dependent). MβCD positive
protocols.null_outcome: Significant GP change (>0.03) in degassed samples, indicating direct mechanical coupling independent of cavitation.

protocols.prediction: IF isolated mitochondria are exposed to 40 kHz ultrasound at 1-3 W/cm² in air-saturated buffer, THEN OMM lipid domain reorganization (Laurdan GP decrease >0.05 and cholesterol-filipin puncta dispersal >30%) will occur; this effect will be abolished (>80% reduction) in degassed buffer.
protocols.protocol: Isolate mitochondria from HeLa/HEK293 cells. Expose to 40 kHz US (0.5, 1.0, 2.0, 3.0 W/cm², 30-120s pulsed) in degassed (<1 mg/L O₂) or air-saturated buffer. Monitor cavitation via broadband noise (passive cavitation detector). Fix immediately, stain with filipin (cholesterol) and NAO (cardiolipin), image by structured illumination microscopy. Assess membrane integrity via cytochrome c release ELISA. Timeline: 3 weeks.
controls: digitonin (0.01%) as membrane permeabilization positive control
protocols.null_outcome: Equal lipid reorganization in degassed and air-saturated conditions, indicating direct mechanical (non-cavitation) mechanism at kHz.

protocols.prediction: IF OMM cholesterol is depleted by MβCD (5-10 mM, 30 min), THEN VDAC1 oligomerization (measured by EGS crosslinking and VDAC1-FRET) will increase >2-fold relative to vehicle, with concurrent loss of VDAC1 honeycomb clustering (>40% decrease in cluster size by STORM).
protocols.protocol: Treat HEK293 and HeLa cells with MβCD (0, 1, 2.5, 5, 10 mM, 30 min, 37°C). For crosslinking: isolate mitochondria, treat with EGS (0.5 mM, 30 min), quench, run SDS-PAGE/Western for VDAC1 (monomer ~32 kDa, dimer ~64 kDa, oligomers >96 kDa). For FRET: transfect VDAC1-mCerulean + VDAC1-mVenus, measure FRET efficiency by acceptor photobleaching. For clustering: fix, immunostain VDAC1, image by STORM. Verify cholesterol depletion by Amplex Red assay on isolated mitochondria. Timeline: 2 weeks.
protocols.expected_outcome: Dose-dependent increase in VDAC1 dimer/oligomer bands (>2-fold at 5 mM MβCD), increased FRET efficiency (>1.5-fold), decreased STORM cluster size (>40%), correlating with cholesterol depletion (>40%). Partial rescue by cholesterol repletion (cholesterol-MβCD complexes).
protocols.null_outcome: No change in VDAC1 oligomeric state or clustering despite >40% cholesterol depletion, refuting lipid-dependent VDAC1 state model.

protocols.prediction: IF cancer cells (MCF-7, HeLa) and matched normal cells (MCF-10A, HEK293) are exposed to graded mechanical perturbation (MβCD titration as lipid disruption proxy, or 40 kHz US with cavitation), THEN cancer cells will show a sharper sigmoidal dose-response curve for VDAC1 oligomerization (Hill coefficient >3 vs. <2 for normal cells) with a higher intensity threshold (EC50 ~1.3-2× that of normal cells), but greater maximal response.
protocols.protocol: Culture MCF-7 vs. MCF-10A and HeLa vs. HEK293 in parallel. First, characterize baseline OMM lipidomes by LC-MS/MS on isolated mitochondria. Then expose to graded MβCD (0-15 mM, 8

final_claims.statement: Diagnostic ultrasound (1-3 MHz, 0.1-3 W/cm²) delivers insufficient mechanical energy to the OMM to reorganize lipid domains directly; attenuation and spatial averaging reduce local OMM stress to sub-threshold levels (<1 pN/nm²).
final_claims.mechanism: At cellular scales (~10 μm), acoustic wavelengths (0.5-1.5 mm at MHz) create near-uniform pressure fields across organelles, producing negligible differential stress across the ~5 nm OMM; radiation force is orders below lipid domain reorganization thresholds.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Direct measurement of OMM lipid order (e.g., Laurdan GP) showing changes during diagnostic-intensity insonation.

final_claims.statement: Low-frequency therapeutic ultrasound (20-100 kHz) at higher intensities can induce cavitation-mediated local stresses sufficient to perturb OMM lipid organization, but this operates through transient cavitation rather than direct mechanical coupling.
final_claims.mechanism: Stable/inertial microbubble oscillations generate localized shear stresses (>100 Pa) and microstreaming that can deform membranes at subcellular scales, disrupting lipid packing order.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Demonstration that OMM lipid reorganization occurs under 20-100 kHz ultrasound in degassed media (cavitation suppressed).

final_claims.statement: VDAC1 oligomeric state is lipid-environment-dependent, with cholesterol stabilizing monomeric/honeycomb states and cholesterol depletion promoting oligomerization-competent dispersed states.
final_claims.mechanism: Cholesterol intercalates at VDAC1 β-barrel interfaces (confirmed by MD and photolabeling), sterically inhibiting the conformational rearrangement required for oligomer contact surfaces; domain disruption liberates VDAC1 from cholesterol-rich rafts.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: VDAC1 oligomerization assays (crosslinking, FRET) showing no change upon cholesterol depletion with MβCD.

final_claims.statement: Cancer cell OMMs, with elevated cholesterol, would paradoxically be MORE resistant to mechanically-induced VDAC1 oligomerization at moderate perturbation, but the compressed phase diagram means a sharper transition once threshold is exceeded.
final_claims.mechanism: Higher cholesterol creates a more ordered liquid-ordered phase with greater mechanical stiffness but narrower coexistence region; once sufficient energy crosses the phase boundary, the transition is cooperative and abrupt.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Comparative dose-response curves of ultrasound intensity vs. VDAC1 oligomerization in cancer vs. normal mitochondria showing monotonic rather than threshold behavior. ───

final_claims.statement: 1:** Ultrasound at 1–3 MHz (0.1–3 W/cm²) can propagate mechanical energy to the OMM with sufficient intensity to disrupt cholesterol/cardiolipin domains, but 20–100 kHz therapeutic US is unlikely to do so at these intensities.
final_claims.mechanism: MHz US generates cavitation and microstreaming near membranes, while kHz US requires higher intensities for comparable mechanical effects due to longer wavelengths and lower energy deposition at the OMM.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: *In vitro* measurements of OMM lipid domain reorganization (e.g., Laurdan GP imaging) under US exposure showing no change at 20–100 kHz but detectable shifts at 1–3 MHz. ---

final_claims.statement: 2:** Reorganization of cholesterol/cardiolipin domains in the OMM can shift VDAC1 from honeycomb (protected) to dispersed (oligomerization-competent) states, but this depends on lipid composition thresholds.
final_claims.mechanism: Cholesterol-rich domains stabilize VDAC1 honeycomb arrays (reduced mobility), while cardiolipin-rich domains favor dispersed states by increasing membrane fluidity and VDAC1 lateral diffusion.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Single-molecule tracking of VDAC1 in synthetic liposomes with defined cholesterol/cardiolipin ratios showing no state transition despite domain reorganization. ---

final_claims.statement: 3:** Cancer cells (elevated OMM cholesterol, reduced cardiolipin) have a lower threshold for US-induced VDAC1 state transitions compared to healthy cells, but the effect size is modest (<2-fold change in US intensity).
final_claims.mechanism: Altered lipid composition in cancer OMMs reduces membrane rigidity, lowering the energy barrier for US-induced domain reorganization and VDAC1 dispersion.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Comparative US exposure studies in healthy vs. cancer cells (e.g., MCF-7) showing no difference in VDAC1 oligomerization thresholds despite lipid profile differences. ---

final_claims.statement: 4:** The mechanical energy required to reorganize OMM lipids exceeds the thermal noise floor but is within the range of clinically relevant US intensities (1–3 MHz, 0.5–3 W/cm²).
final_claims.mechanism: Lipid domain reorganization requires ~10⁻²⁰–10⁻¹⁹ J per molecule (estimated from membrane bending rigidity), achievable via MHz US microstreaming at 1–3 W/cm².
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Molecular dynamics simulations or atomic force microscopy showing no lipid domain disruption at these US parameters. --- ───

final_claims.statement: Ultrasound mechanical energy at 0.1-3 W/cm² propagates to OMM with ~0.1-2 MPa pressures, exceeding lipid reorganization thresholds (~0.1 MPa shear).
final_claims.mechanism: Wavelength (15-150 μm) >> cell/mito size (1-10 μm), minimal attenuation; p_rms = √(2ρcI) yields MPa stresses via streaming/cavitation.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Intracellular pressure mapping (e.g., optical tweezers) showing <0.1 MPa at mito.

final_claims.statement: Lipid domain reorganization by mechanical stress destabilizes VDAC1 honeycomb lattice, promoting dispersed/oligomeric state.
final_claims.mechanism: Cholesterol/CL rafts stabilize VDAC1 hexamers; shear disrupts packing, exposing oligomerization interfaces (per MD sims of VDAC-lipid interactions).
final_claims.falsifiable_by: VDAC1 FRET/EM under US showing no lattice disruption despite lipid mixing (FRAP).

final_claims.statement: Cancer OMMs (↑cholesterol ~2x, ↓CL ~50%) have lower threshold (~0.5x I) for US-induced VDAC1 transition vs. healthy cells.
final_claims.mechanism: Elevated chol rigidifies domains but reduces CL-VDAC affinity, making lattice fragile to lower shear.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Dose-response curves (oligomerization vs. I) identical in cancer/healthy mito liposomes.

final_claims.statement: No direct evidence links clinical US to VDAC1 oligomerization via lipids.
final_claims.mechanism: Literature shows US membrane effects (sonoporation) but not OMM-specific VDAC1 state change.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Peer-reviewed study demonstrating US-VDAC1 oligomerization in intact cells. ───

final_claims.statement: Ultrasound at clinically relevant frequencies and intensities can deliver sufficient mechanical energy to the OMM to transiently disrupt lipid microdomains.
final_claims.mechanism: Acoustic radiation force and cavitation-induced shear stress generate pressure and strain fields within the cell that exceed the low energy barriers for lipid lateral diffusion and phase separation.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Super-resolution imaging of fluorescently-labeled cholesterol and cardiolipin in the OMM of isolated mitochondria showing no spatial reorganization during sonication at 3 W/cm².

final_claims.statement: The honeycomb lattice of VDAC1 is stabilized by cardiolipin-rich domains, and its disruption by cholesterol enrichment or mechanical perturbation promotes a dispersed, oligomerization-competent monomeric state.
final_claims.mechanism: Cardiolipin facilitates VDAC1-VDAC1 interactions that form the protected honeycomb structure, while cholesterol acts as a "spacer" that breaks these interactions, releasing monomers.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Cryo-EM studies showing that VDAC1 maintains a honeycomb arrangement in synthetic liposomes with high cholesterol and low cardiolipin content, or that it disperses under mechanical stress regardless of lipid composition.

final_claims.statement: The altered lipidome of cancer cell OMMs lowers the acoustic energy threshold required to induce VDAC1 dispersal and subsequent oligomerization.
final_claims.mechanism: The pre-existing high cholesterol/low cardiolipin environment in cancer OMMs poises the VDAC1 honeycomb in a less stable state, requiring less external energy to trigger its collapse into dispersed monomers.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: A dose-response experiment showing that the ultrasound intensity required to induce VDAC1-mediated apoptosis is identical for cancer cells and their healthy counterparts. ───

final_claims.statement: Ultrasound at therapeutic kHz frequencies (20-100 kHz) is more likely than diagnostic MHz frequencies to propagate mechanical energy capable of reorganizing OMM lipid domains.
final_claims.mechanism: Lower frequency, longer wavelength ultrasound experiences less scattering/absorption in cytoplasm, allowing deeper mechanical (non-thermal) effects like cavitation/microstreaming that can exert shear forces on membranes.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Direct measurement showing MHz-range pulses cause greater OMM lipid displacement than kHz at equivalent spatial peak temporal average intensities.

final_claims.statement: Reorganization of OMM cholesterol-rich lipid domains can shift VDAC1 from a honeycomb to a dispersed state.
final_claims.mechanism: VDAC1 localization and oligomerization are modulated by lipid environment; cholesterol depletion disperses VDAC1 clusters, implying mechanical disruption of cholesterol domains would have a similar effect.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Showing that ultrasound-induced VDAC1 dispersion occurs even in cholesterol-depleted OMMs where domains are already disrupted.

final_claims.statement: Cancer cell OMMs (high cholesterol) have a lower threshold for ultrasound-induced VDAC1 dispersion than healthy cell OMMs.
final_claims.mechanism: Elevated cholesterol increases membrane rigidity and order; a more ordered domain may require less mechanical energy to disrupt and release VDAC1 from its confined honeycomb arrangement.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Experimental data showing healthy cells require lower ultrasound intensity to achieve the same degree of VDAC1 dispersion as cancer cells. ───
